title: Segundo Mercado
text:
Laurensio Segundo Mercado (born 5 January 1967) is a retired male <a href="Boxing">boxer</a> from <a href="Ecuador">Ecuador</a>.
Mercado represented Ecuador at the <a href="1988%20Summer%20Olympics">1988 Summer Olympics</a>, losing on points in the <a href="Boxing%20at%20the%201988%20Summer%20Olympics">boxing competition</a> to <a href="Martin%20Kitel">Martin Kitel</a> of <a href="Sweden">Sweden</a>. He turned professional after the games and, fighting as a <a href="middleweight">middleweight</a>, built up a record of 18-2.
On 17 December 1994, Mercado was matched against future <a href="Undisputed%20championship%20%28boxing%29">undisputed</a> middleweight champion <a href="Bernard%20Hopkins">Bernard Hopkins</a> for the vacant <a href="International%20Boxing%20Federation">IBF</a> middleweight title in <a href="Quito%2C%20Ecuador">Quito, Ecuador</a>. Attempting to become his country's first ever world boxing champion, Mercado knocked Hopkins down twice, but the fight was scored a controversial <a href="split%20draw">split draw</a>. They met again four months later, and this time Hopkins won via a seventh round <a href="Knockout">technical knockout</a>.
Mercado moved up to the <a href="super-middleweight">super-middleweight</a> division after losing to Hopkins, and challenged <a href="World%20Boxing%20Association">WBA</a> super-middleweight champion <a href="Frankie%20Liles">Frankie Liles</a>; Mercado was stopped in five rounds. Mercado continued boxing, but failed to win another fight and retired in 2003 with a final record of 19-10-2.
